name: What is my opinion about Knockout VS Angular ? « GuruStop.NET (@Meligy)
caption: gurustop.net
description: My Angular.JS video is getting way more traction than I thought, with over 2K views and a lot of comments on Youtube and Facebook. One of the comments on Facebook came today was:

data.message: AngularJS it's one more "hipster" library. only used until another one comes up. Usually a new one rises because the old one wasn't "enough" for production.
In theory what comes next is not a library, but a standard. The Web Components standard. I find Angular.JS very functional though, if you are building most of the UI yourself especially.

I find it hard to recommend it now knowing its going through very big refactoring now that will show maybe by the time of 1.2 (maybe end of this year? not sure). For the same reason I expect it'll cover the main current problems, but it also means a lot of the APIs will feel obsolete shortly.
Knockout is easier for people who don't have a lot of experience in JS, while Angular covers more areas. The whole area of SPAs is new & we will witness a lot :)

from supporting multi culture teams including tens of developers for over a year at a previous client, I can tell you from first hand experience that Knockout in real world large applicants can be very problematic for those starters who are not comfortable with JS. In Angular. js though the only thing that new people seem to keep hitting is understanding inheritance in child scopes, which is becoming very common that there are very good resources about it now already

Both Knockout and AngularJS will disappear in a couple of Month as the trend is going way farther to the use of Web components and less playing with the DOM :) introducing the new Shadow DOM. Mozilla Already released their Web Components Library (https://hacks.mozilla.org/2013/05/speed-up-app-development-with-x-tag-and-web-components/) and Google Just Announced their components [here](http://html5-demos.appspot.com/static/webcomponents/index.html) and the video introduction is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=0g0oOOT86NY
